item.title: Assignment
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“xpatx, post:4, topic:432181”][quote author=Speljohan link=topic=534893.msg3910686#msg3910686 date=1328699175]
for outputData i would probably override toString so:

public String toString() {
    return "[" + getWidth() + "," + getHeight() + "," + getArea() + "," + isSquare() + "]";
}

Or something like that. Then you could just do

public void doShit() {
    Rectangle r = new Rectangle(20, 10);
    System.out.println(r);
}

[/quote]

Yes, but I’m calling the method from another class which is my RectangleDemo.

[code]public class RectangleDemo {

public static void main(String[] args) {
	Rectangle r1 = new Rectangle();
	r1.outputData();
	
	System.out.println();
	
	Rectangle r2 = new Rectangle(4, 5);
	r2.outputData();
	
	System.out.println();
	
	Rectangle r3 = new Rectangle(26); //was trying to get this to work with the one parameter.
	r3.outputData();
}

}[/code]

And thank you sinisoul, appreciate the help man.[/quote]toString is a public function, you can access it from any context.

Read full topic

item.title: Assignment
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

The second part I understand is just turning it into a square that has close to the same area as the rectangle. So given: width, height.

Some psuedo code:

totalArea = width * height
width = height = sqr(totalArea) //Cast to integer.

Quadratize just refers to the method name, I believe.

With one parameter just means that the construction would look like:

Rectangle(int len) {
    this.width = this.height = len;
}

Read full topic

item.title: Assignment
item.dc:creator: @xpatx xpatx
item.description:
@xpatx wrote:

[CODE]public class Rectangle {

private int width, height;

public Rectangle() {
	width = 1;
	height = 1;
}

public Rectangle(int area) {

}

public Rectangle(int width, int height) {
	this.width = width;
	this.height = height;
	
	if(width < 0 || height < 0) {
		System.out.println("Error: not valid!");
	}
}

public void checkIfSquare() {
	if(isSquare() == true) {
		System.out.println("It is a square.");
	} else if (isSquare() == false) {
		System.out.println("It is a rectangle.");
	}
}

public void outputData() {
	System.out.println("Width: " + getWidth());
	System.out.println("Height: " + getHeight());
	System.out.println("Area: " + getArea());
	checkIfSquare();
}

public boolean isSquare() {
	return (width == height);
}

public int getArea() {
	int sideArm = (int) Math.sqrt(width * height);
	int area = sideArm * sideArm;
	
	return area;
}

public int getWidth() {
	return width;
}

public int getHeight() {
	return height;
}

}[/CODE]

[QUOTE]Step 1. Write a class called Rectangle that represents a rectangle with integer width and height. Include a constructor that builds a rectangle with a given width and height and another constructor (with one parameter) that builds a rectangle that is actually a square of a given size. Make sure these constructors check that the width and height are positive. Add a constructor that takes no parameters and builds a square of size 1.

Step 2. Add a boolean method isSquare that returns TRUE if and only if the rectangle is a square. Add a method quadratize that converts this rectangle into a square with approximately the same area - the closest possible for a square with an integer side.

Step 3. Define several rectangles, check which ones among them are squares and print appropriate message. “Quadratize” one of the rectangles, verify that it becomes a square, print an apporpriate message. [/QUOTE]

Those are the instructions, but I do not understand two things.

  1. What is to “quadratize” a rectangle?

  2. “another constructor (with one parameter) that builds a rectangle that is actually a square of a given size.” What does my teacher mean by this? I clearly do not understand.

Read full topic
